indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: National strategy developed for mainstreaming the health risks of climate change into health sector policies and programmes

baseline.comment: No health policy and operational response in place

target.comment:
1. Methods and Indicators are identified to measure climate change resilience in the health sector.
2. Health Sector Medium Term Development Plan specifies gender-sensitive actions to address the health risks of climate change, and mechanisms for implementation in Ghana.
3. Assess national, regional, district and sub-district surveillance systems for CSM, diarrheal disease, and malaria to determine specific activities where adjustments could be implemented to address the additional health risks of climate change
4. Climate change projections for Ghana to identify where and when adjustments could be implemented at national, regional, district and sub-district levels are conducted.
5. Gender sensitive climate resilience screening tool for the health sector in Ghana developed.
6. Initiate the establishment of Teleconsultation medicine Centre in each of the three pilot sites of the project.

actual.comment:
1. Methods and Indicators have been identified to measure climate change resilience in the health sector. The project has identified a number of methods and indicators to help measure climate change resilience in the health sector. These methods and indicators are now being integrated in the medium term health sector of the Ministry of Health.
2. Health Sector Medium Term Development Plan specifies gender-sensitive actions to address the health risks of climate change, and mechanisms for implementation in Ghana. The project has conducted a review of the Health Sector Medium Term development strategy (HSMDS) to incorporate gender sensitive actions into the HSMDS of the ministry of health. These gender sensitive actions are being integrated into the 2014-2017 HSMDS of Ghana.
3. The project has also assessed at the national, regional, district and sub-district surveillance systems for CSM, diarrheal disease, and malaria to determine specific activities where adjustments could be implemented to address the additional health risks of climate change in Ghana.
4. Climate change projections for Ghana have been conducted. Through these projections, a number of measures both medium and long terms have been identified for implementation at national, regional, district and sub-district levels 5. Gender sensitive climate resilience screening tool for the health sector in Ghana have been developed. Beyond the stool, guidelines have also been developed to help in the use of the tool at both the national and subnational levels.
6. Equipment have been procured aimed at establishing Teleconsultation Centres in each of the three pilot sites of the project in 2015.

target.comment: 1. Establish Teleconsultation Centres in the three Pilot Districts 2. Develop National Action Plan for Climate Change Adaption for the Health Sector 3. Review the health sector medium term development plan to incorporate climate change in health sector planning 4. Assess the current M&E systems as well as develop proposal on methods of strengthening the data management systems of the health sector so that it incorporates climate change resilience indicators 5. Assess the nature and quality of data from existing relevant surveillance systems (health, food security, nutrition, environmental, meteorological and climate) and develop a method for integrating data into health information management systems 6. Develop methods for capturing, recording and disseminating best practices and lessons learned under the climate change and health project and also for incorporation into the health sector central database 7. Implement Climate Change and Health awareness activities at three Pilot districts 8. Conduct end of project evaluation

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: -Local Government Service Secretariat produce monitoring report on decentralisation process -Local administrative staff trained in decentralisation process -debates organised on constitutional reforms -knowledge products on the code and NMC monitoring function produced and distributed -citizens more aware of about policy options in electoral agendas -increased capacity of EC staff, media and citizen to work together -increase in the rate of women and the vulnerable activity working toward reaching leadership and decision-making positions

baseline.comment: -Tracing mechanisms to assess decentralisation progress are weak -lack of awareness about decentralisation process among local administrative staff -limited public discussions and awareness of CRC recommendations -Breaches of the media code of conduct -Citizens not well informed about electoral agendas -need for more civic education content in the curriculum -level of public confidence in the administration of elections -low representation of women and vulnerable groups in decision making and leadership positions

target.comment: 1. Average rating of local government service performance being “very or fairly well” is 50% by end-2014 2. 60% of all decentralisation recommendations in Government’s White Paper implemented (activated) by end-2014 3. Six key governance institutions with the capacity to strategically plan, monitor and evaluate the success of their programs by 2014 4.57% of males and 50% of females sampled attended at least one public meeting in 2014 5. 54% of Ghanaians trust political parties “somewhat” or “a lot” by end-2014 6.15% women elected into the local Assemblies in 2014 local elections 7. Four (4) platforms established and/or supported to promote women’s participation in decision-making processes by 2014 8. Average of 50% increase in key technical capacities for women groups and PWD group leaders as well as average of 50% skills usage 6 months after capacities built

actual.comment: Key staff of MMDAs were trained in impact assessment and gender statistics and sex dis-aggregated data collection and management as well in report writing skills ( 13 female and 8 males) benefited. Post training assessment confirmed that 65% of participants demonstrated improved skills. Also with support from UNDP the IMCC enhanced the capacity of 125 staff to be able to engage effectively with leadership and authority of PRCCs (16 female and 104 males). Through this, a Consolidated Local Government bill has expanded the role of PRCC based on the feedback from capacity building workshops. TheYouth Bridge Foundation (and NGO) was also supported to develop the capacity of 228 youth (111males and 117 female) from Asogyaman and Gomoa West Districts sensitized in major local policy discussions on public hearing. Post training assessment evidenced that 62% demonstrated improved capacity and enhanced skills in engaging authorities. UNDP also supported the Ministry of Gender Women and Social Protection to collaborate with National Affirmative Action Legal Committee and Gap Institutions to review and make inputs into the draft Affirmative Bill. Finally, as part of support to LOGNET , UNDP facilitated platforms that enabled 210 (people with disability) PWDs engage district assemblies to advocate their rights and privileges

target.comment: 1) : 40% (NB target will be appropriately adjusted when baseline is determined by GAP Poll ) of voter population have some knowledge in the proposed constitutional amendments recommended by the Constitution Review Report by 2016 (source GAP Poll 2016) 2) 60% of citizens trust the Electoral Commission to deliver on its mandate by the end of 2016 3) National policy on Popular Participation in Local Governance 100% developed and validated by end-2016 4) Baseline reduced to 70% by end-2016 5) total of 25,000 citizens participating in nationwide governance assessments by end of 2016 6) Six (6) initiatives established and/or supported to promote women’s participation in decision-making processes by 2016 7): Developed baseline on HIV related stigma and discrimination by 2016

iati-activity.description: The project seeks to deepen the culture and practice of transparency and accountability at the local governance level while strengthening the administration of justice and the capacity of citizens to access the legal system.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: -Number and level of consultations on policy formulationss and decision making -Number of citizens participating in local governance assessments (including vulnerable groups) district assembly debates validation workshops through APRM structures. -Increased public confidence in he administration of justice -increased numbers of women and vulnerable groups access the justice system

baseline.comment: -Inadequate engagements between citizens and governance/public institutions -noticeable low levels of citizens response to the Citizens Report Card (11,078 citizens), participation in the district assembly debates (1032) and validation workshop (11968) -Weaknesses in legal framework and institutional capacity hampering the delivery of justice -Paucity of legal professionals in specialised fields

target.comment: 1) 20000 citizens participate in platforms for accountability in 80 districts 2) Parliament approve the NACAP document

actual.comment: With UNDP’s support 33,299 citizens; made up of 17,284 males 16,015 females participated in platforms for accountability established in over 80 districts through governance assessment and regular interface meetings between duty bearers and right holders led to improvements in service delivery. Parliamentary engagements supported resulted in the approval of the National Anti-Corruption Action Plan (NACAP) after almost two years. Through targeted sensitization, key stakeholders, including religious leaders and the media are aware of their role in implementing the NACAP. Recommendations of the UNDP supported UNCAC Ghana country review will be implemented to further strengthens efforts at fighting corruption. According to the 2014 Afrobarometer survey, the perception of corruption among tax officials of the Ghana Revenue Authority reduced marginally from 90% in 2012 to 85% in 2014 as a result of the implementation of key actions in the communication strategy developed for the service in 2013. 650 ombudsman/Administrative Justice cases were received and resolved as result of the training received by 267 (194 males and 73 females )officers of CHRAJ across the Institutional strengthening support for the Legal Aid Scheme have through the development and use of a 5 year strategic plan, a personnel strategy, Legal Aid guide, a website, the development and printing of the over 70,000 brochures, and organization of a legal aid clinics in 10 districts have resulted in a reduction in the number of people with no knowledge on the Legal Aid Scheme the baseline of 79% to 68% according to the GaP Poll’s December, 2014 results and an increase in Legal Aid personnel from 40 to 70

target.comment: 1) Public service integrity programme operational 2) Review and adopt at least one anti-corruption legislation 3) Baseline reduced to 80% 4) 80 MDAs and MMDAs have published Client Charters by 2015 5) 460 cases reported and 400 resolved 6) At least one criminal justice institution operating a functional case management system 7) Baseline reduces to 60%

iati-activity.title: SE4ALL Action Plan Implementation Supported
iati-activity.description: UNDP will provide strategic support to the Government of Ghana for the implementation of the Sustainable Energy for All Action Plan.

iati-activity.title: SE4ALL Implementn. Supported
iati-activity.description: The project will support the establishment of a regulatory framework for the improved cookstoves market in Ghana and the development of an action oriented monitoring and evaluation of energy access system.

transaction.disbursement-channel: Money is disbursed directly to the implementing institution and managed through a separate bank account
Money is disbursed directly to the implementing institution and managed through a separate bank account
Money is disbursed directly to the implementing institution and managed through a separate bank account
Money is disbursed directly to the implementing institution and managed through a separate bank account
Money is disbursed directly to the implementing institution and managed through a separate bank account

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: - Standards for improved cookstoves available - International impact oriented indicators available in the GEAR toolkit

baseline.comment: - Ghana developed the SE4ALL Action Plan, focused on the promotion of productive uses of energy and access to modern forms of fuels for cooking (e.g. LPG and improved cookstoves) - No technical standards for improved cookstoves available in Ghana - Impact oriented energy access indicators not identified and utilized in energy access measurements in Ghana

target.comment: - Equipment for cookstoves and testing facility procured and installed - Awareness creation campaign on clean cookstoves initiated - Enhanced GEAR toolkit operational and effectively used by planning institutions

actual.comment:
1) REGULATORY FRAMEWORK FOR THE IMPROVED COOKSTOVES MARKET IN GHANA ESTABLISHED: - Draft standards for the improved woodfuel cookstove sector have been developed by a technical committee led by the Ghana Standards Authority. As of 31 December 2014, the standards have been published to get comments from the general public. They are expected to be finalized and gazetted in 2015. - A cookstove testing and expertise centre has been established at the Technology Consulting Centre (TCC) of the Kwame Nkrumah University of Science and Technology (KNUST). This will enable all locally produced or imported cookstoves to be comprehensively tested to ensure that they meet minimum efficiency, performance, technical and emissions standards before being certified for use in the country. - A consumer segmentation survey and a cookstove sector stakeholder mapping were conducted to identify the target for the awareness creation campaign.
2) GHANA'S ACTION-ORIENTED MONITORING AND EVALUATION OF ENERGY ACCESS SYSTEM DEVELOPED: - With the expertise of the Energy Center of KNUST, the Ghana Energy Access Toolkit was developed, which uses Geographical Information System (GIS) techniques to provide data on access to electricity, LPG and renewable energy sources. The toolkit will be used for both planning and monitoring purposes. - A web-based application to access the toolkit on the website of the Ghana Energy Commission was developed.
3) SOLAR PV SYSTEMS FOR SUSTAINABLE IRRIGATION IN 4 COMMUNITIES IN NORTHERN GHANA ESTABLISHED: - UNDP and Energy Commission collaborated with New Energy, a local NGO, to establish solar systems for irrigation (one type of productive uses of energy listed in the SE4All Action Plan) in Northern Ghana. - In all, the irrigation facilities will produce up to 1 million liters of water daily to benefit 61 farm families, consisting of 550 persons, with the potential to put under irrigation up to 26 hectares of land.

target.comment: - Technical standards for improved cookstoves gazetted - Testing and certification center at TCC fully operational by December 2015 - Stakeholders educated on the cookstoves standards developed and the benfits of using improved cookstoves over traditional ones. - Zero used refrigerators entering Ghana market - 15,000 refrigerators exchanged through the rebate scheme

iati-activity.title: Resilient Landscapes
iati-activity.description: The Resilient Landscapes for Sustainable Livelihoods is a project implemented in partnership with the Government of Ghana and four UN Agencies to strengthen the resilience of vulnerable communities in northern Ghana.

iati-activity.title: Resilient Landscapes

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1) Number of consultative meetings on RE policy and gaps in Ghana held. 2) Report on barriers for RET transfer produced 3) Report on criteria and specifications for selection of 4 RETs 4) number and type of training packages developed 5) number of reports and surveys developed and published; 6) Roadmap launched and disseminated; 7) Documents establishing PMUs and PSCs exist

baseline.comment: 1) Ghana adopted the Renewable Energy Act in 2011, but there is no master plan to implement it. 2) Barriers to effective transfer of Renewable Energy existed. 3) Currently, there is no demonstration site set up for Renewable Energy Technology Transfer (RETT) 4) There is no mechanism for up-scaling of RETs for Public-Private actors established, and capacity building required 5) The UNDP South-South Cooperation Framework 6) There is no existing mechanism for promoting Renewable Energy Technology Transfe 7) PMUs and PSCs haven’t been established.

target.comment: 1) Review of Chinese and Ghanaian Renewable Energy Policies conducted. 2) Report on barriers completed 3) Report on criteria and specifications for selection of 4 RETs developed and submitted to China 4) Minimum of 3reports on China’s national and regional planning approaches, laws and programs, institutional set ups, technology capacity, and financial models produced and shared 5) A meeting for a task force responsible for China-Ghana Renewable Energy Technology Transfe (RETT) financing through the SSC center 7) Stakeholder list developed; Project organization established; regular meetings held

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1) Levels of public trust in political parties (source: Afrobarometer/GaP Poll) 2) % of female party members willing to contest for leadership positions 3)Levels of public trust in the Electoral Commission (source: GaP Poll) 4) # of IPAC meetings held in election year 5) Number of polling station results submitted to J-PERM within 48 hrs of the close of poll

baseline.comment: 1) 50.5% of Ghanaians trusted political parties “somewhat” or “a lot” in 2012. 3) 57% of Ghanaians trust the Electoral Commission “somewhat” or “a lot” in 2014 to deliver on its mandate 4) 2 meetings held in 2012 5) 19,000 polling station results submitted in 2012

target.comment: 1) Gender Policies and strategies in women participation in political parties placed 2) International Best practices in internal political parties 3) Support main political parties to conduct a baseline and develop membership database 4) Relaunch the Project to gain traction and serve as resource mobilization tool 5) Participate in International best practice meeting and recommend solutions for local adoption

iati-activity.title: Green Climate Fund Readiness Programme in Ghana
iati-activity.description: To support the Government of Ghana in strengthening their national capacities to effectively and efficiently plan for, access, manage, deploy and monitor climate financing in particular through the GCF once it is fully operational.

iati-activity.title: GCF Readiness Programme in Gh
iati-activity.description: To support the Government of Ghana in strengthening their national capacities to effectively and efficiently plan for, access, manage, deploy and monitor climate financing in particular through the GCF once it is fully operational

transaction.disbursement-channel: Money is disbursed directly to the implementing institution and managed through a separate bank account
Money is disbursed directly to the implementing institution and managed through a separate bank account
Money is disbursed directly to the implementing institution and managed through a separate bank account

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: - Number of national entities identified and assessed for National Implementing Entities (NIE) potential - Number of workshops held to strengthen climate change coordination - Reconstitution of the NCCC - Number of tools developed for economic and budget analysis of climate finance - Number of online knowledge management platforms to support project pipelines - Number of workshops to train stakeholders on prioritising procedures - Number of tools developed to assess and design climate interventions - Number of MRV templates developed

baseline.comment: - Ghanaian public and private entities not assessed for existing fiduciary governance capacity - No workshops held to strengthen coordination - National Climate Change Committee is not currently active - No tools developed for climate finance related economic and budget analysis - No online knowledge management platform to support project pipelines - No trainings for stakeholders on prioritising interventions - No tools developed to assess and design climate interventions - No MRV templates or guidance

target.comment: 1. Mapping and assessment of Ghanaian national public or private entities that are eligible to access funds from the GCF complete 2. Ghana’s climate change coordination across national and sub-national levels strengthened 3. Strengthening of climate change regulations, policies, plans and budgeting supported 4. Stakeholder access to information and knowledge products on climate change increased 5. Guidelines and procedures developed for prioritizing climate change needs and interventions 6. Market based and value chain business model tools developed to assess, design and measure climate change interventions, including Cost-Benefit Analysis (CBA) and project checklists and safeguards 7. Monitoring and evaluation (MRV) templates and guidance developed

actual.comment:
The GCF readiness programme started implementation from June 2015 with the inception workshop, as the fund was only received to the country office in May. Following the inception, a half-day workshop was organized in August with the support from the GCF secretariat to increase stakeholder’s knowledge on the National Implementing Entities (NIEs) accreditation requirement and process. In November, National Designated Authority (NDA) for GCF, Real Sector Division of Ministry of Finance, advertised a call for application to identify potential NIEs candidates in Ghana. Capacity assessment of the identified entities will be conducted as a next step.
In order to strengthen climate change coordination, the project supported Ministry of Environment, Science, Technology, and Innovation (MESTI) to organize the National Climate Change Steering Committee. The committee reviewed Ghana’s progress in the preparation of Intended Nationally Determined Contributions to UNFCCC, and discussed the formation of working groups under the committee including climate finance working group.
The consultants were engaged to 1) develop the operational manual for NDA and 2) develop the climate change project prioritization tool. The prioritization tool will be used by national stakeholders to identify and prioritize the areas for GCF proposal development. Further, building up from the outcome of the Climate Public Expenditure and Institutional Review conducted by Ministry of Finance earlier this year, the project will support the development of the climate change budget and finance tracking tool.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1) Report covering the celebration of the International Day for DRR 2) Minutes and approved programme for the annual review meeting of the national platform 3) Draft and final awareness creation materials submitted 4) Core Training Agenda developed 5) Report on regional and district simulation exercises organised.

baseline.comment: 1) The is annual event, and has been celebrated in previous year including 2014 2) National platform already exist 3) There are existing materials but need to be updated 4) There is existing literature and different training programmes with various academic and learning institutions 5) Similar prepared and awareness stimulation exercise are in place

target.comment: 1) Organize high level, public events, in particular within the context of the International Day for DRR, to raise awareness on specific topics and issues related to DRR in Ghana. 2) Support awareness and advocacy activities organized by the National Platform for DRR 3) Develop awareness creation material for disaster risk reduction and prevention. 4) Develop a core training agenda addressing disaster risk reduction and management for government cadres from various administrative levels. 5) Organize 1 regional and 1 district simulation exercises to strengthen disaster preparedness.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1) No stock out of reagents and supplies for testing EVD; # of temperature screening equipment installed 2) Number of personnel trained; Number of situation reports expected generated; Number of protective and preventive items provided; Number of immigration officers trained; Number of entry/exit sites that conduct EBV surveillance; Childhood disease management protocol available; Number of community-based surveillance volunteers trained

baseline.comment:
The Ebola Virus Disease (EVD) outbreak was first reported to WHO in March 2014. As at 29 October 2014, about 14,000 cases and nearly 5,000 deaths have been recorded mainly from the three most affected countries, Guinea, Liberia and Sierra Leone.
Ghana is considered as being at high risk of importation of EVD in view of a combination of varied number of factors which have the potential to trigger an outbreak which will have a devastating impact on health, economic, social, security and overall development of the country. Some of these factors include
